channel.title: History on JW Caterine
channel.description: Recent content in History on JW Caterine

item.title: New Podcast!
item.description: I started a podcast as part of my weekly newsletter Round the Triangle this week. For the inaugural episode, we are talking about James Blair, the co-founder of the College of William & Mary and, as it turns out, a slaveholder and advocate for institutionalized slavery in colonial Virginia. Despite this legacy, Blair is still honored today as the namesake of a local middle school and a hall on W&M campus. You can listen here.

item.title: Documentary on First Integrated Graduating Class in Williamsburg
item.description: The Local Black Histories Project put together a compelling film about the experiences of Black students who first integrated in the WJCC school system. There will be another screening at the Williamsburg Regional Library on Sunday, Nov. 19 at 2 PM.

item.title: New Roof for Jamestown Church Tower
item.description:
This story will be my last about Historic Jamestown for the foreseeable future, but I still plan on going back as a visitor, including to see the progress on this project!

Ribbon-cutting at Historic Jamestown to commemorate new roofing at the church tower, the only remaining 17th century above ground structure on site. pic.twitter.com/aRqFrCKB6v

— J Duh Yuh (@jwcat757) October 4, 2023

item.title: Jamestown Archaelogists Discover Sword Fragments
item.description: Archaeologists at Historic Jamestowne found sword and dagger fragments, likely from three different weapons, in the “Governor’s Well.”

item.title: Governor's Well Excavation
item.description: In my previous reporting on Historic Jamestown, I’ve mentioned past well excavations they’ve done, but it is exciting to be able to report on one happening in real time. The team there has been super welcoming and even let me climb into the excavation cribbing around the dig. Who knows what they’ll find?

item.title: New Tours at Jamestown
item.description: I covered the new tours at Historic Jamestown. It is quickly becoming one of my favorite places to visit locally.

item.title: Historic Jamestowne Volunteers
item.description: I had the chance to go behind the scenes at Historic Jamestowne and meet some of the volunteers who work in the conservation lab as well as interpreters at the fort site. As a teenager visiting Historic Jamestowne, I mostly remember the heat. Now as an adult who actually appreciates history, I found everything there fascinating. It is very much an active archaeological site with new digs happening all the time, and I plan to go back soon. I also uploaded some supplemental interviews I did to youtube:
